options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Zoom final presentation
Also virtual office hours
virtual seminar with recorded audio files.
Recording available for those who missed class.
Some recorded lecture due to technical difficulties
virtual office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An incredible amount. I learned to view the world through a geological lens, including plate tectonics, rock types and how they're formed, hydrology, energy, minerals, our mantle and core, and Earth's formation.
Better understanding of earth's history and geology, presentation skills, and a renewed sense of happiness.
Basic geology/how to identify different geological aspects of the Earth

This was a very valuable course to me. I learned a ton about geology and the world we live on generally, and a ton about my hometown which was really cool. I became very familiar with using google earth.
I gained a broad, introductory understanding of geological and earth systems processes.
How our planet works and how many geological processes are connected.

The course was focused around being able to visualize and recreate geologic landscapes of one location throughout geologic history. I gained a deeper understanding of plate tectonics and stratigraphy.
I learned about the geology of my hometown and how to recognize geological patterns in everyday nature.
I gained much knowledge about the geological processes happening around us/
I learned about the basics of geology in an approachable and enjoyable way!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Evans is a great teacher. The lectures were excellent, delivering lots of knowledge in a concise and understandable way. The only "weakness" I perceived related to the remote nature of the course; it would have been great to have a few more opportunities to engage.
Very good course! I think it did a good job balancing the opportunity of going into more depth while laying a strong foundation of geology.

This class was really interesting and was overall taught well. I think that having the lab component to be able to actually see real examples of what we are talking about would have been nice to have, but understandably it was cancelled due to COVID.

This course was very engaging even for being fully virtual. Lectures were great and well thought out. The professors and teaching staff were all very friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable. The workload was very manageable and homework assignments were actually compelling and very interesting. It definitely would have benefitted from being in person, but honestly, it was much better than almost all of my other virtual courses. I didn't really meet anyone from the class because of the wide range of majors/class years/etc. and because the course was online, and I would have liked to maybe interacted more with the other students.

The weekly homework assignments were a great way to ensure we were understanding course material.  I also thought it worked really well to have a portion of our final research project assigned in each homework.  That way, at the end of the semester we had most of our research compiled.  It made compiling the final project fun and interesting instead of stressful.

Strengths: Professor Evans, he is a great speaker and easy to follow along with. Lectures are short and concise.
Weaknesses: Chapter readings from the book did not always translate to the homework set or help.

The order in which the course material is presented is very logical and easy to comprehend. The homework sets were relevant to the content covered in lectures and ample help was available if needed. I found that even the times at which lectures were held were optimal. 

The only weakness of this course that would not have been an issue in a non-pandemic year would be that there were no hands-on examples or in-person engagement with specimens relevant to the course material.

strengths - there were no tests, psets only, and final was comprised of psets

Weakness - the lectures could be a little dull at times because of the lack of interaction
Strengths: problem sets were interesting, TFs were very available, Professor Evans is extremely knowledgable.
It was a great course overall. The only thing I would have liked to see would have been qualitative feedback on the problem sets I wasn't quite sure what I might not have understood.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were great, as were the homework assignments. As above, some more breakout rooms or polling would have been welcome to further stay engaged.
Everything went well - maybe having recordings with the slides would be more helpful than just the audio - but I always attended class, so that didn't affect me
The lectures were good, but I wish there had been more interaction. Since it was a small class it would have been nice to do more breakout rooms / things that would help us interact more.

The virtual lectures were great! Obviously being in person and forming that community would have been better, but it went generally pretty well. One thing that could definitely be improved is that there weren't many (really any?) opportunities to interact with the other students in class, so I didn't form connections with any other students in the course.
Live lectures and occasional breakout rooms were nice, made it feel as in-person as it could.

The use of PowerPoints during lecture and breakout rooms to discuss how the content related to our experiences were most effective. The course could be most improved by requiring participation for a grade in the future, as complete engagement is sometimes difficult over a virtual platform.
While the instructors sprinkled in a few breakout room sessions here and there, the engagement between students was practically nonexistent.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. It's a great introduction to Earth sciences and science more generally. Learn to view the world with a more in depth, richer perspective.
Yes! super fun content. interesting enough and not too hard.
Of course. Take this class. Professor Evans was the most engaged and kind professor I've had at Yale.
This class is really interesting and would be good for anyone regardless of major, so yes

I would certainly recommend this course! If you're thinking about the EPS major, this is really great. If you just need a science credit, I would definitely recommend this as well!! You learn so much about the world around you, and what you learn is really applicable to understanding the physical spaces around you. The hometown project is also fantastic!
Yes.  It was a really interesting introductory science course that would be great for non-STEM majors interested in earth sciences.
Yes, however, it helps a lot more if you have any bit of prior knowledge about geology and geological processes. Homework sets were relatively easy but time consuming towards the end of the course.

Yes yes yes!!!! Professor Evans is great, and the course is very informative, interesting, and fun. If you are looking for a science gut, look elsewhere. If you are looking for a science credit that will teach you a lot of interesting concepts from geology and broaden your horizon, look no more: this is the class to take!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, whether they were interested in pursuing the earth sciences further or not. Learning about local geology sheds new light on a variety of different issues or unique qualities about a location, from economic growth to the ability to extrapolate potential future issues for a community of people.
I would recommend this course if you're looking for a science credit! This is the one to take non-stem majors.
Yes! It's so important to understand how the world around us works and Professor Evans delivers that information in an engaging way.
Yes! It's an awesome course, and David Evans is a fantastic professor.
